solutions.content:
![check if it is a straight line.PNG](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/58ae45a1-a274-4249-b45e-dab2de6071f1_1685998087.723891.png)


# Intuition
Calculate a & b in y = ax + b then check if coordinates[i] is alligned with our line by replacing y and x and validating the equation.
# Approach
1. We start by calculating `deltaY` and `deltaX`, which are used to calculate the slope `a` and the y-intercept `b`. They are generated from the first two coordinates because we only need to check if the remaining coordinates are on the same line.
2. `a` is generated by dividing `deltaY` by `deltaX`.
3. `b` is generated by using the first coordinate and calculating `b = y - a * x`.
4. If `deltaX === 0` this means we have a vertical line, then we check if all the points have the same x-axis coordinate `coordinate[i][0]`, if not we return false.
5. If `deltaY === 0` this means we have a horizontal line, then we check if all the points have the same y-axis coordinate `coordinate[i][1]`, if not we return false.
6. If neither `deltaX` nor `deltaY` are 0, then we check the y = ax + b equation for every coordinate, and if it is not validated we return false. 
7. If no single case fails, we return true.

# Complexity
- Time complexity:O(N)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:O(1)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
function checkStraightLine(coordinates: number[][], deltaY = null, deltaX = null, a = null, b = null): boolean {
  deltaY = coordinates[1][1] - coordinates[0][1]
  deltaX = coordinates[1][0] - coordinates[0][0]
  a = deltaY/deltaX
  b = coordinates[0][1] - a * coordinates[0][0]
  for ( let i = 1; i < coordinates.length; i++ ) {
    if ( deltaX === 0 ) {
      if ( coordinates[i][0] !== coordinates[i - 1][0]) return false
    }
    else if ( deltaY === 0 ) {
      if ( coordinates[i][1] !== coordinates[i - 1][1]) return false
    }
    else {
      if ( coordinates[i][1] !== a*coordinates[i][0] + b ) return false
    }
  } 
  return true
};
```

# If You like the Solution, Don't Forget To UpVote Me, Please UpVote! 🔼🙏
# Runtime: 111 ms, faster than 25.34% of Python3 online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.
# Memory Usage: 14.3 MB, less than 80.33% of Python3 online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.

	class Solution:
		def checkStraightLine(self, coordinates: List[List[int]]) -> bool:

			dy = (coordinates[1][1]-coordinates[0][1])
			dx = (coordinates[1][0]-coordinates[0][0])

			for i in range(1,len(coordinates)-1):

				next_dy = (coordinates[i+1][1]-coordinates[i][1])
				next_dx = (coordinates[i+1][0]-coordinates[i][0])

				if dy * next_dx != dx * next_dy:
					return False

			return True
			
# Runtime: 80 ms, faster than 27.29% of Python3 online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.
# Memory Usage: 16.8 MB, less than 50.49% of Python3 online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.

	class Solution:
		def checkStraightLine(self, coordinates: List[List[int]]) -> bool:

			result = 1
			first = coordinates[0]
			second = coordinates[1]

			dy1 = (second[1] - first[1])
			dx1 = (second[0] - first[0])

			for coordinate in coordinates[2:]:

				dy2 = (coordinate[1] - second[1])
				dx2 = (coordinate[0] - second[0])

				second = coordinate

				if dy1 * dx2 != dy2 * dx1:
					return False

# Runtime: 111 ms, faster than 25.34% of Python3 online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.
# Memory Usage: 14.3 MB, less than 80.33% of Python3 online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.

	class Solution:
		def checkStraightLine(self, coordinates: List[List[int]]) -> bool:

			dy = (coordinates[1][1]-coordinates[0][1])
			dx = (coordinates[1][0]-coordinates[0][0])

			for i in range(1,len(coordinates)-1):

				next_dy = (coordinates[i+1][1]-coordinates[i][1])
				next_dx = (coordinates[i+1][0]-coordinates[i][0])

				if dy * next_dx != dx * next_dy:
					return False

			return True

			second = coordinates[1]

			dx1 = (second[0] - first[0])

			for coordinate in coordinates[2:]:

				dy2 = (coordinate[1] - second[1])
				dx2 = (coordinate[0] - second[0])

				second = coordinate

solutions.content:
##### Leetcode: 1232. Check If It Is a Straight Line.

Idea behind this solution is that slope between first point and all others must be the same. What is a slope, it is a quotient between x distance and y distance of two points, it called dx and dy. First calculate slope between first two points, and than compare slope between first point and rest of them with first slope. 

It is may happens that dy or dx are the same because it is horizontal or vertical line, and y and x values are same between all points respectively. These cases are added two.


Ruby code:
```Ruby
# Leetcode: 1232. Check If It Is a Straight Line.
# https://leetcode.com/problems/check-if-it-is-a-straight-line/
# Runtime: 44 ms, faster than 83.33% of Ruby online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.
# Memory Usage: 9.8 MB, less than 58.33% of Ruby online submissions for Check If It Is a Straight Line.
# @param {Integer[][]} coordinates
# @return {Boolean}
def check_straight_line(coordinates)
    c = coordinates
    
    return true if c.all?{|(a,b)| a == c[0][0]}
    return true if c.all?{|(a,b)| b == c[0][1]}
    
    a,b = c[0],c[1]
    dx = a[0] - b[0]
    dy = a[1] - b[1]
    slope = dx.fdiv(dy)
    
    c[2..-1].each do |b|
        dx = a[0] - b[0]
        dy = a[1] - b[1]
        return false if slope != dx.fdiv(dy)
    end
    
    true
end
```

solutions.content:
```
class Solution(object):
    def checkStraightLine(self, coordinates):
        """
        :type coordinates: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: bool
        """
# if number of points is 2 return true
        if len(coordinates) == 2:
            return True
        x1,y1 = coordinates[0][0],coordinates[0][1] # get coordinates of first point
        x2,y2 = coordinates[1][0],coordinates[1][1] # get coordinates of second point 
# check if x2-x1 -> zero division case
        if x2-x1 == 0:    
            return False
        diff = (y2-y1)/(x2-x1) # compute  slope 
        i = 2 # start loop from coordinates [2]
        while i < len(coordinates):
# zero divison case
            if coordinates[i][0] - coordinates[i-1][0] == 0:
                return False
# compute slope between current point and the previous point
            diff_ = (coordinates[i][1]-coordinates[i-1][1])/(coordinates[i][0] - coordinates[i-1][0])
			
# check if slope not equal to slope of first two points return false as points aren't on same straight line
            if diff_ != diff:  
                return False
            i += 1
        return True
            
```

class Solution(object):
    def checkStraightLine(self, coordinates):
        """
        :type coordinates: List[List[int]]
        :rtype: bool
        """
# if number of points is 2 return true
        if len(coordinates) == 2:
            return True
        x1,y1 = coordinates[0][0],coordinates[0][1] # get coordinates of first point
        x2,y2 = coordinates[1][0],coordinates[1][1] # get coordinates of second point 
# check if x2-x1 -> zero division case
        if x2-x1 == 0:    
            return False
        diff = (y2-y1)/(x2-x1) # compute  slope 
        i = 2 # start loop from coordinates [2]
        while i < len(coordinates):
# zero divison case
            if coordinates[i][0] - coordinates[i-1][0] == 0:
                return False
# compute slope between current point and the previous point
            diff_ = (coordinates[i][1]-coordinates[i-1][1])/(coordinates[i][0] - coordinates[i-1][0])
			
# check if slope not equal to slope of first two points return false as points aren't on same straight line
            if diff_ != diff:  
                return False
            i += 1
        return True
            
```

content.content:
There are at least 3 things you should know to solve this.

* Remember when in high school you asked your teacher *Who cares what is the slope between two points? When am I going to use this anyway?*, well, this is one of those situations. So, remember: 
$$m = (y_2 - y_1) / (x_2 - x_1)$$
* It would be easy to solve this if the points were sorted... Right?
* There is a border case: What if two points have the same `x` value? Ouch. That would be a division by zero. Think how to take care of this particular case.

Those tips should do the trick for you. Happy coding.

[@theRadFad](/theRadFad) Yeah, sorting won\'t be helpful here at all. The reason is that you can either sort in the direction of x or in the direction of y. If the points were in a straight line, they would already appear sorted in some direction (either x or y). So, in that case, you don\'t get any advantage by sorting. I suppose its not needed.
Lovely hints. I would just like to add that, perhaps, sorting may not be that important .. right?

Use standard form so you don't have to deal with vertical lines (division by zero).
$$y-y_1 =  m(x-x_1)$$
$$y-y_1 =  (y/x)(x-x_1)$$
$$x(y-y_1) = y(x-x_1)$$
Hint: try vector method as opposed to Cartesian method
This should be marked as medium problem\n
Writing the code is piece of cake if you remember the line equation from Highschool
Why? It\'s just a basic high school mathematics problem.

To check if three points are in straight line or not we try to assume it as a triangle and if the area of traingle if zero then we say that the three points are in straight line.

The solution to this question is you take the first 2 points and check for every point if with any point the first two points makes a triangle of a positive area the answer is no that the coordinates are not in straight line.

The formula to calculate area is (1/12)*(x1(y2-y3) + x2(y3-y1) + x3(y1-y2)) apply the same formula learnt in school

This is a question for the school math. Every point (x[i], y[i]) (for i!=0, 1)on the line satisfies
$
(y[i]-y[0])/(x[i]-x[0])=(y[1]-y[0])/(x[1]-x[0])=$slope of this line

but be careful, not divided by zero. Before submitting, try the following test case:
```
[[0,0],[0,1],[0,-1]]
```
[https://youtu.be/00BEcax1fu8](https://youtu.be/00BEcax1fu8)

Hints for those who want to code on their own:

1. 2 points are always co-linear.
2. 3 points are co-linear if the slope of lines joining any 2 of the 3 points is same.
3. Be a bit careful while calculating slope. The denominator might be 0.
Finally a real Good Morning after a scary fortnight.

tan(0)=(y2-y1)/(x2-x1)
for multiple points.
(y2-y1)/(x2-x1)==(y1-y0)/(x1-x0)
But in this 0/0 exception come.
So rearrange the formula. 
**(y2-y1)*(x1-x0)==(y1-y0)*(x2-x1)**

CODE is solution section.

2. 3 points are co-linear if the slope of lines joining any 2 of the 3 points is same.
3. Be a bit careful while calculating slope. The denominator might be 0.
Finally a real Good Morning after a scary fortnight.

tan(0)=(y2-y1)/(x2-x1)
for multiple points.
(y2-y1)/(x2-x1)==(y1-y0)/(x1-x0)
But in this 0/0 exception come.
So rearrange the formula. 
**(y2-y1)*(x1-x0)==(y1-y0)*(x2-x1)**

CODE is solution section.

coordinates =
[[0,0],[0,1],[0,-1]]
Output
false

true
[@RomNc](/RomNc) But according to question, we have to "Check if these points make a straight line in the XY plane or not". So, I can't see anything wrong.

[@Rajat310](/Rajat310) The points form a straight line, but mathematically speaking the gradient of a vertical line is undefined. So, this one another amiguously presented question on leetcode. 
The point is we need to apply some sort of mathemataical formula to solve this problem, while a vertilcal line is not a case to which this mathematical formula can be applied. But anyways...
[@artem09122002](/artem09122002) It is true. The x-coordinates are all the same(i.e. constant) and thus form a straight line on the x-axis regardless of the y-axis.

There are at least 3 things you should know to solve this.

* Remember when in high school you asked your teacher *Who cares what is the slope between two points? When am I going to use this anyway?*, well, this is one of those situations. So, remember: 
$$m = (y_2 - y_1) / (x_2 - x_1)$$
* It would be easy to solve this if the points were sorted... Right?
* There is a border case: What if two points have the same `x` value? Ouch. That would be a division by zero. Think how to take care of this particular case.

Those tips should do the trick for you. Happy coding.

[@theRadFad](/theRadFad) Yeah, sorting won\'t be helpful here at all. The reason is that you can either sort in the direction of x or in the direction of y. If the points were in a straight line, they would already appear sorted in some direction (either x or y). So, in that case, you don\'t get any advantage by sorting. I suppose its not needed.
Lovely hints. I would just like to add that, perhaps, sorting may not be that important .. right?

Use standard form so you don't have to deal with vertical lines (division by zero).
$$y-y_1 =  m(x-x_1)$$
$$y-y_1 =  (y/x)(x-x_1)$$
$$x(y-y_1) = y(x-x_1)$$
Hint: try vector method as opposed to Cartesian method
This should be marked as medium problem\n
Writing the code is piece of cake if you remember the line equation from Highschool
Why? It\'s just a basic high school mathematics problem.

To check if three points are in straight line or not we try to assume it as a triangle and if the area of traingle if zero then we say that the three points are in straight line.

The solution to this question is you take the first 2 points and check for every point if with any point the first two points makes a triangle of a positive area the answer is no that the coordinates are not in straight line.

The formula to calculate area is (1/12)*(x1(y2-y3) + x2(y3-y1) + x3(y1-y2)) apply the same formula learnt in school

This is a question for the school math. Every point (x[i], y[i]) (for i!=0, 1)on the line satisfies
$
(y[i]-y[0])/(x[i]-x[0])=(y[1]-y[0])/(x[1]-x[0])=$slope of this line

but be careful, not divided by zero. Before submitting, try the following test case:
```
[[0,0],[0,1],[0,-1]]
```

[@RomNc](/RomNc) But according to question, we have to "Check if these points make a straight line in the XY plane or not". So, I can't see anything wrong.

[@Rajat310](/Rajat310) The points form a straight line, but mathematically speaking the gradient of a vertical line is undefined. So, this one another amiguously presented question on leetcode. 
The point is we need to apply some sort of mathemataical formula to solve this problem, while a vertilcal line is not a case to which this mathematical formula can be applied. But anyways...
[@artem09122002](/artem09122002) It is true. The x-coordinates are all the same(i.e. constant) and thus form a straight line on the x-axis regardless of the y-axis.

There are at least 3 things you should know to solve this.

* Remember when in high school you asked your teacher *Who cares what is the slope between two points? When am I going to use this anyway?*, well, this is one of those situations. So, remember: 
$$m = (y_2 - y_1) / (x_2 - x_1)$$
* It would be easy to solve this if the points were sorted... Right?
* There is a border case: What if two points have the same `x` value? Ouch. That would be a division by zero. Think how to take care of this particular case.

Those tips should do the trick for you. Happy coding.

[@theRadFad](/theRadFad) Yeah, sorting won\'t be helpful here at all. The reason is that you can either sort in the direction of x or in the direction of y. If the points were in a straight line, they would already appear sorted in some direction (either x or y). So, in that case, you don\'t get any advantage by sorting. I suppose its not needed.
Lovely hints. I would just like to add that, perhaps, sorting may not be that important .. right?

Use standard form so you don't have to deal with vertical lines (division by zero).
$$y-y_1 =  m(x-x_1)$$
$$y-y_1 =  (y/x)(x-x_1)$$
$$x(y-y_1) = y(x-x_1)$$
Hint: try vector method as opposed to Cartesian method
This should be marked as medium problem\n
Writing the code is piece of cake if you remember the line equation from Highschool
Why? It\'s just a basic high school mathematics problem.

To check if three points are in straight line or not we try to assume it as a triangle and if the area of traingle if zero then we say that the three points are in straight line.

The solution to this question is you take the first 2 points and check for every point if with any point the first two points makes a triangle of a positive area the answer is no that the coordinates are not in straight line.

The formula to calculate area is (1/12)*(x1(y2-y3) + x2(y3-y1) + x3(y1-y2)) apply the same formula learnt in school

This is a question for the school math. Every point (x[i], y[i]) (for i!=0, 1)on the line satisfies
$
(y[i]-y[0])/(x[i]-x[0])=(y[1]-y[0])/(x[1]-x[0])=$slope of this line

but be careful, not divided by zero. Before submitting, try the following test case:
```
[[0,0],[0,1],[0,-1]]
```
[https://youtu.be/00BEcax1fu8](https://youtu.be/00BEcax1fu8)

Hints for those who want to code on their own:

1. 2 points are always co-linear.
2. 3 points are co-linear if the slope of lines joining any 2 of the 3 points is same.
3. Be a bit careful while calculating slope. The denominator might be 0.
Finally a real Good Morning after a scary fortnight.

tan(0)=(y2-y1)/(x2-x1)
for multiple points.
(y2-y1)/(x2-x1)==(y1-y0)/(x1-x0)
But in this 0/0 exception come.
So rearrange the formula. 
**(y2-y1)*(x1-x0)==(y1-y0)*(x2-x1)**

CODE is solution section.

There are at least 3 things you should know to solve this.

* Remember when in high school you asked your teacher *Who cares what is the slope between two points? When am I going to use this anyway?*, well, this is one of those situations. So, remember: 
$$m = (y_2 - y_1) / (x_2 - x_1)$$
* It would be easy to solve this if the points were sorted... Right?
* There is a border case: What if two points have the same `x` value? Ouch. That would be a division by zero. Think how to take care of this particular case.

Those tips should do the trick for you. Happy coding.

[@theRadFad](/theRadFad) Yeah, sorting won\'t be helpful here at all. The reason is that you can either sort in the direction of x or in the direction of y. If the points were in a straight line, they would already appear sorted in some direction (either x or y). So, in that case, you don\'t get any advantage by sorting. I suppose its not needed.
Lovely hints. I would just like to add that, perhaps, sorting may not be that important .. right?

Use standard form so you don't have to deal with vertical lines (division by zero).
$$y-y_1 =  m(x-x_1)$$
$$y-y_1 =  (y/x)(x-x_1)$$
$$x(y-y_1) = y(x-x_1)$$
Hint: try vector method as opposed to Cartesian method

To check if three points are in straight line or not we try to assume it as a triangle and if the area of traingle if zero then we say that the three points are in straight line.

The solution to this question is you take the first 2 points and check for every point if with any point the first two points makes a triangle of a positive area the answer is no that the coordinates are not in straight line.

The formula to calculate area is (1/12)*(x1(y2-y3) + x2(y3-y1) + x3(y1-y2)) apply the same formula learnt in school

This is a question for the school math. Every point (x[i], y[i]) (for i!=0, 1)on the line satisfies
$
(y[i]-y[0])/(x[i]-x[0])=(y[1]-y[0])/(x[1]-x[0])=$slope of this line

[[0,0],[0,1],[0,-1]]

1. 2 points are always co-linear.
2. 3 points are co-linear if the slope of lines joining any 2 of the 3 points is same.
3. Be a bit careful while calculating slope. The denominator might be 0.

This method won\'t work if the points are vertically aligned (hint: the gradient is NOT zero).
be careful, not divided by zero

Slope Calculation: The main idea to solve this problem is to calculate the slope between consecutive points.

Initial Slope: Calculate the slope between the first two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) as slope = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1).

Comparing Slopes: For each subsequent point (xi, yi), calculate the slope between the previous point and the current point.

Handling Vertical Lines: To handle vertical lines where (x2 - x1) is zero, check if the denominator is zero before calculating the slope. If it's zero, set the current slope to a unique value (e.g., double.MaxValue).

Compare Slopes: Compare the current slope with the initial slope. If any of the calculated slopes are different, return false, indicating that the points do not form a straight line.

Return true: If all slopes are equal, return true, indicating that the points form a straight line.

Basic geometry:

1. If Every coordinates have same slope then they form a straight line.
2. Lets assume you are give two coordinates in a plan (x1,y1), (x2,y2).
3. Then slope 'm' is equal to (y2-y1) / (x2-x1).
4. What if (x2-x1)=0? (then slop becomes undefined) see my solution understand more.

Got it, thanks
yep, it is a valid case, all coordinates describe vertical line - i.e., x is constant for all points, y can be different
it is a straight line on the x-axis regardless of where the y-values are.

Basic geometry:

1. If Every coordinates have same slope then they form a straight line.
2. Lets assume you are give two coordinates in a plan (x1,y1), (x2,y2).
3. Then slope 'm' is equal to (y2-y1) / (x2-x1).
4. What if (x2-x1)=0? (then slop becomes undefined) see my solution understand more.
check my solution to handle edge cases  https://leetcode.com/problems/check-if-it-is-a-straight-line/solutions/3601634/easy-java-explained-approach/

How would you do this in high dimension?
How do you in higher dimension? It could be a plane in R^3, or  (n-1)-dimensional hyperplane in R^(n-1). Or just  on a line?

First, subtract the first vector from all the vectors. This just moves the first point to the origin. Now all the points are colinear if and only if every point is a scalar multiple of the second vector.

This method won\'t work if the points are vertically aligned (hint: the gradient is NOT zero).
be careful, not divided by zero

Slope Calculation: The main idea to solve this problem is to calculate the slope between consecutive points.

Initial Slope: Calculate the slope between the first two points (x1, y1) and (x2, y2) as slope = (y2 - y1) / (x2 - x1).

Comparing Slopes: For each subsequent point (xi, yi), calculate the slope between the previous point and the current point.

Handling Vertical Lines: To handle vertical lines where (x2 - x1) is zero, check if the denominator is zero before calculating the slope. If it's zero, set the current slope to a unique value (e.g., double.MaxValue).

Compare Slopes: Compare the current slope with the initial slope. If any of the calculated slopes are different, return false, indicating that the points do not form a straight line.

Return true: If all slopes are equal, return true, indicating that the points form a straight line.

Just solved this in Java. I was so confused when my code gave the wrong answer. I calculated the slope for the first two points and then found the line intercept using c = y - m*x. Whenever (x2 - x1) was zero, I used Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY. Then I checked if the next successive pairs of points have the same slope and intercept. But I was getting wrong answers for some test cases. The intercept becomes NaN when the slope is infinity. Turns out using "!=" operator between two NaN\'s was the problem (NaN != NaN is true in Java lol). Fixed that and it passed all cases
The question does not explicitly state that points are sorted by x, but this is critical, because if we sort them, the time-complexity drops from "O(n) beats 100%" to "O(n*log(n)) beats 5%".
There is no reason as to why you should sort the points. Thus, it should not matter either way
That is because you have to typecast coordinates[i][1]-coordinates[i-1][1] to float before dividing\n

any two points will always make a straight line, so find the slope, then traverse the input and find slope for each two consecutive points, like if A,B  & B,C lies in a straight line definitely A,C is in straight line. But make sure to check for vertical line, coz there the slope will be infinite,\n\nformula for slope = (y2-y1)/(x2-x1)
check with the slope of first two points, slope of two points is y2-y1/x2-x1  To get rid of edge case do not divide just do cross multiplication (dx1*dy2 = dy1*dx2)

The major point of discussion in the question "Check if these points make a straight line in the XY plane" is to determine if a given set of points lie on a straight line. This involves understanding the geometric properties of a line and applying them to the given set of points. One approach to solving this problem is to calculate the slope between pairs of points and check if it is the same for all pairs. Another approach is to use cross product to check if the points are collinear.
checking if the cross product always result in 0, we can see if the points are on a straight line:\n(x2\u2212x1)(y3\u2212y1)\u2212(y2\u2212y1)(x3\u2212x1)

The major point of discussion in the question "Check if these points make a straight line in the XY plane" is to determine if a given set of points lie on a straight line. This involves understanding the geometric properties of a line and applying them to the given set of points. One approach to solving this problem is to calculate the slope between pairs of points and check if it is the same for all pairs. Another approach is to use cross product to check if the points are collinear.

A deceptively easy question. I wonder how many other programmers had to revise their algorithms several times as new test cases failed.

Some high school algebra: the slope of a line through any 2 points is 
m = (y0 - y1) / (x0 - x1) = (y1 - y2) / (x1 - x2). Of course, it could be that xi = xj so this can't be used directly. However, we can cross multiply:
(y0 - y1) * (x1 - x2) = (y1 - y2)  * (x0 - x1) will be true if the 3 points are collinear.

So go with the test: ``(y[i] - y[i+1]) * (x[i+1] - x[i+2]) == (y[i+1] - y[i+2]) * (x[i] - x[i+1])``

Do i just check if the next point is on the same "diagonal" , i.e mod(xj - xi) = mod(yj - yi) ?
i think this would be faster than comparing slopes
[@artyomushko](/artyomushko) oh ok thanks
The line is not always a diagonal. So [[0,0],[1,2],[2,4]] will not pass your code

A little Geometry lesson: 
**COLLINEAR POINTS**

-We have a formula to get area of triangle from three coordinates
i.e:
area=0.5*[x1 * (y2 - y3) + x2 * (y3 - y1) + x3 * (y1 - y2)]
The above is derived from [shoelace formula](https://www.geeksforgeeks.org/area-of-a-polygon-with-given-n-ordered-vertices/)

-if the area is=0
then that means all points in a same line i.e. straight line
thus the 3 points are said to be **Collinear Points**

So go with the test: ``(y[i] - y[i+1]) * (x[i+1] - x[i+2]) == (y[i+1] - y[i+2]) * (x[i] - x[i+1])``

-if the area is=0

title: Minimum Number of Removals to Make Mountain Array
question_content:
You may recall that an array arr is a mountain array if and only if:

  • arr.length >= 3
  • There exists some index i (0-indexed) with 0 < i < arr.length - 1 such that:
    • arr[0] < arr[1] < ... < arr[i - 1] < arr[i]
    • arr[i] > arr[i + 1] > ... > arr[arr.length - 1]

Given an integer array nums, return the minimum number of elements to remove to make nums a mountain array.

 

Example 1:

Input: nums = [1,3,1]
Output: 0
Explanation: The array itself is a mountain array so we do not need to remove any elements.

Example 2:

Input: nums = [2,1,1,5,6,2,3,1]
Output: 3
Explanation: One solution is to remove the elements at indices 0, 1, and 5, making the array nums = [1,5,6,3,1].

 

Constraints:

  • 3 <= nums.length <= 1000
  • 1 <= nums[i] <= 109
  • It is guaranteed that you can make a mountain array out of nums.

solutions.content:
# Intuition Longest increasing sequence
# Explanation Pick A[1],A[2],..,A[n-2] as the peak value, find on the longest increasing sequence on its left and on its right. The maximum mountain = left + right - 1
# Solution 1, brute force this ides **Python:** Time O(n^2logn), Space O(n) ```py def minimumMountainRemovals(self, A): n = len(A) def longest(A): mono = [10**9] * n for a in A: i = bisect.bisect_left(mono, a) mono[i] = a return i if i else -n return n - max(longest(A[:i + 1]) + longest(A[:i - 1:-1]) + 1 for i in xrange(1, n - 1)) ```
# Solution 2, two passes **Python** Time O(nlogn), Space O(n) ```py def minimumMountainRemovals(self, A): n = len(A) dp = [0] * n mono = [10**9] * n for i in xrange(n): j = bisect.bisect_left(mono, A[i]) mono[j] = A[i] dp[i] += j + 1 if j else -n mono = [10**9] * n for i in xrange(n - 1, -1, -1): j = bisect.bisect_left(mono, A[i]) mono[j] = A[i] dp[i] += j if j else -n return n - max(dp[1:-1]) ```
solutions.code:
```py
    def minimumMountainRemovals(self, A):
        n = len(A)

        def longest(A):
            mono = [10**9] * n
            for a in A:
                i = bisect.bisect_left(mono, a)
                mono[i] = a
            return i if i else -n
        return n - max(longest(A[:i + 1]) + longest(A[:i - 1:-1]) + 1 for i in xrange(1, n - 1))
```
```py
    def minimumMountainRemovals(self, A):
        n = len(A)
        dp = [0] * n
        mono = [10**9] * n
        for i in xrange(n):
            j = bisect.bisect_left(mono, A[i])
            mono[j] = A[i]
            dp[i] += j + 1 if j else -n
        mono = [10**9] * n
        for i in xrange(n - 1, -1, -1):
            j = bisect.bisect_left(mono, A[i])
            mono[j] = A[i]
            dp[i] += j if j else -n
        return n - max(dp[1:-1])
```

solutions.content:
left[i] means length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence that ends at nums[i]
```
from bisect import bisect_left

class Solution:
    def minimumMountainRemovals(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        def LIS(nums):
            longest = []
            res = []
            for x in nums:
                if not res or longest[-1] < x:
                    longest.append(x)
                    res.append(len(longest))
                else:
                    idx = bisect_left(longest,x)
                    longest[idx] = x
                    res.append(idx+1)
            return res
        left = LIS(nums)
        right = LIS(nums[::-1])
        res = float('inf')
        n = len(nums)
        for i in range(1,len(nums)-1):
            res = min(res, n-(left[i] + right[-i-1] - 1) if left[i]>=2 and right[-i-1]>=2 else float('inf'))
        return res
```

solutions.content: ``` def minimumMountainRemovals(nums): dp_begin = [1]*len(nums) dp_end = [1]*len(nums) for i in range(len(nums)): for j in range(i+1): if nums[j] < nums[i]: dp_begin[i] = max(dp_begin[j]+1, dp_begin[i]) maxi = 0 for i in range(len(nums)): maxi = max(maxi, dp_begin[i]) dp_begin[i] = maxi for i in range(len(nums)-1, -1, -1): for j in range(i+1, len(nums)): if nums[j] < nums[i]: dp_end[i] = max(dp_end[j]+1, dp_end[i]) maxi = 0 for i in range(len(nums)-1, -1, -1): maxi = max(maxi, dp_end[i]) dp_end[i] = maxi best = 0 for i in range(1, len(dp_begin)-1): if dp_begin[i] != 1 and dp_end[i] != 1: best = max(best, dp_begin[i]+dp_end[i]) return len(nums)-best+1 ``` - the **main idea** is that we want to calculate **largest increasing subsequence** (LIS) up until a index `i` and the **largest decreasing subsequence** (LDS) onwards from index `i` doing this will help us select an index as mountain peak that will still keep as many elements as possible - after getting this LIS dp array, we still need to update each index to have the **cummalative max** and for LDS dp array, we also need to calculate cummalative max but starting from right to left since we want all elements to the left of a certain index to be decreasing - lastly, calculate the **biggest sum between each index in LIS dp array and LDS dp array** and substract 1 since the mountain peak was included twice (one for each dp array) this max sum is the total of all elements included in the mountain array -> so subtract this max sum from `len(nums)` to get total elements removed below, I just go over an example:

solutions.content:
### Binary Search + DP
Let's observe the mountain array first. 
In order to make it mountain array with peak at index *i*, we need guarrentee the intergers to the left of *i* is strictly increasing and the integers to the right of *i* is strictly decreasing. Besides, we want to remove the minimum number of integers from the *nums*. So we need select the one with the longest length sum of increasing sequence to the left and decreasing sequence to the right.
You might have got the idea, we calcuate the longest increasing subsequence to the left and right respectively using DP for each index, and pick up the one with the longest length.
The pitfall here is that we need reverse the *nums* to calculate the increasing subsequence to the right and reverse the dp array back.
Note, we only care about those with non zero length from left and right side since the peak can't be the edge (index 0 and len - 1)
Finally, we just get the result by subtracting the longest length of mountain from the array length.

```python
def minimumMountainRemovals(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
	n = len(nums)
        
    def lis(nums):
		longest = []
        length = [1] * n
        for i, num in enumerate(nums):
			index = bisect.bisect_left(longest, num)
            if index == len(longest):
				longest.append(num)
			else:     
				longest[index] = num
			length[i] = index
		return length

	left = lis(nums)
    right = lis(nums[::-1])[::-1]
 
    max_length = 1    
    for i in range(1, n - 1):
		if left[i] and right[i]:
			max_length = max(max_length, left[i] + right[i] + 1)
	return n - max_length
```

*Time Complexity*= **O(NlgN)**
*Space Complexity*= **O(N)**

solutions.content:
This is a brilliant example of how longest increasing subsequence (LIS) could be applied.

**Idea**

The idea is simple: The minimum number of elements to remove is equivalent to the maximum length subsequence which is also a moutain.

**Algorithm**

For each index i, we find the longest increasing subsequence starting from index 0.
For each index i, we find the longest decreasing subsequence starting from index i, which is equivalent to the longest increasing subsequence starting from index n-1.

**Implementation 1: plain DP**

complexity: O(n^2)
space O(n)

```python
class Solution:
    def minimumMountainRemovals(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        def LIS(nums):
            dp = [1] * n
            for i in range(1, n):
                for j in range(i):
                    if nums[i] > nums[j]:
                        dp[i] = max(dp[i], dp[j] + 1)
            return dp
        
        n = len(nums)
        inc = LIS(nums)
        dec = list(reversed(LIS(nums[::-1])))
        
        return n - max(inc[i] + dec[i] - 1 for i in range(1, n - 1))
```

**Implementation 2: patience sorting**

Complexity O(nlogn)
Space O(n)

```
def minimumMountainRemovals(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        def LIS(nums):
            dp = [1] * len(nums)
            deck = []
            for i in range(len(nums)):
                index = bisect.bisect_left(deck, nums[i])
                if index == len(deck):
                    deck.append(nums[i])
                else:
                    deck[index] = nums[i]
                dp[i] = index + 1
            return dp
        
        n = len(nums)
        inc = LIS(nums)
        dec = list(reversed(LIS(nums[::-1])))
        return n - max(inc[i] + dec[i] - 1 for i in range(1, n - 1))
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->
I find the length of the longest bitonic subsequence and subtract the len of array 

To find the longest Bitonic Subsequence, 
I calculate the Longest increasing subsequence forward and backward.
Then I reverse my backward DP again so there's an index match when calculating the longest length for the bitonic subsequence. However, I still dont understand why those test cases are failing :(

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def minimumMountainRemovals(self, nums: List[int]) -> int:
        #Find the Length of the Longest Bitonic Sequence and subtract it from the length of the array 

        lisF = self.LongestIncreasingSubsequence(nums)
        lisB = self.LongestIncreasingSubsequence(nums[::-1])

        longestBitonic = 1
        for i in range(len(nums)):
            if lisF[i] > 1 and lisB[::-1][i] > 1:
                longestBitonic = max(longestBitonic, lisF[i] + lisB[::-1][i] - 1)
        
        return len(nums) - longestBitonic


    def LongestIncreasingSubsequence(self, nums):
        dp = [1] * len(nums)

        for i in range(1, len(nums)):
            for j in range(i):
                if nums[j] < nums[i] and dp[i] <= dp[j]:
                    dp[i] = 1 + dp[j]
                
        
        return dp 
        
```

content.content:
Calculate the length of the Longest Increasing Subsequence (LIS) as well as the length of the Longest Decreasing Subsequence (LDS) for each index i and store them in two arrays.

Now, if we consider each index as a potential peak of a mountain array, the answer for each index is given by `LIS[i] + LDS[i] - 1`.

Return nums.length - maximum answer obtained from all indices.
[@geekyshark](/geekyshark) yes did the same on it
also just check LIS[i] && LDS[i] both are not equal to one, as it will mean that the i considered as peak will make the array either strictly increasing (LDS[i]=1) or strictly increasing (LIS[i]=1)
[@Rachit_Agnihotri](/Rachit_Agnihotri) its already assured in the question that we can always make a mountain array\n
it will fail as the peak should be between the array. it will fail in case of purely increasing or decreasing sequence
ans for this test case should be 1. 9,8,1,7,6,5,4,3,2,1]. if we remove 1, at 2nd index(0 based indexing)
[@bruteforce007](/bruteforce007) can you elaborate why we did that
no thats true for a bitonic sequence but not true for a mountain array, mountain array will be 1 7 6 5 4 3 2 1
The main part of this problem is to optimize the LIS algorithm which can be done in O(nlogn) and rest is easy.

a=Find longest increasing subsequence
x=Find longest decreasing subsequence

ans=number of elements in vector - (a+x-1)

a+x-1 = gives maximum length of bitonic array we want to find minimum nmumber of removals , so we can subtract maximum length from the size of the vector to get the number of removals.
Consider only the indices from i=1 to n-2 as specified in the question.\nAlso consider only those left and right subsequences which have length greater than 1.
Why for the input [1,1,1,2,2,3,3,3,4,5,8,4,3,2,1] answer is 5 instead of 7 ?\nThe mountain should be [3,4,5,8,4,3,2,1].
The mountain should be [1,2,3,4,5,8,4,3,2,1],that\'s why answer is 5.
While solving just remember : arr is a mountain array if and only if: arr.length >= 3....\nand u have done it!!!!

title: Maximum Product of the Length of Two Palindromic Subsequences
question_content:
Given a string s, find two disjoint palindromic subsequences of s such that the product of their lengths is maximized. The two subsequences are disjoint if they do not both pick a character at the same index.

Return the maximum possible product of the lengths of the two palindromic subsequences.

A subsequence is a string that can be derived from another string by deleting some or no characters without changing the order of the remaining characters. A string is palindromic if it reads the same forward and backward.

 

Example 1:

Input: s = "leetcodecom"
Output: 9
Explanation: An optimal solution is to choose "ete" for the 1st subsequence and "cdc" for the 2nd subsequence.
The product of their lengths is: 3 * 3 = 9.

Example 2:

Input: s = "bb"
Output: 1
Explanation: An optimal solution is to choose "b" (the first character) for the 1st subsequence and "b" (the second character) for the 2nd subsequence.
The product of their lengths is: 1 * 1 = 1.

Example 3:

Input: s = "accbcaxxcxx"
Output: 25
Explanation: An optimal solution is to choose "accca" for the 1st subsequence and "xxcxx" for the 2nd subsequence.
The product of their lengths is: 5 * 5 = 25.

 

Constraints:

  • 2 <= s.length <= 12
  • s consists of lowercase English letters only.

solutions.content:
Binary
- Step 1: find all palindromic subsequences
- Step 2: for each pair of palindromic string, if there is no disjoint, calculate the product, update the max product value

Tips to improve performance:
Use binary to generate all possible subsequences,
cache both the binary represent and length of the word
if two word binary and is zero, there is no overlap

for exampe: for word "abcd"

0100 means "b"
0010 means "c"

0100 & 0010 = 0, therefore, there is no overlap

same logic
0100 means "b"
0110 means "bc"
0100 & 0110 != 0, thereforem, there is overlap

```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        all_palindromic_subsequences = []
        
        n = len(s)
        
        def isPalindromic(word):
            l, r = 0, len(word) - 1
            while l <= r:
                if word[l] != word[r]:
                    return False
                l += 1
                r -= 1
            return True
        
        for i in range(1 << n):
            cur = ""
            for j in range(n):
                if i & (1 << j) != 0:
                    cur += s[j]
            if cur and isPalindromic(cur):
                all_palindromic_subsequences.append((i, len(cur)))
        
        mx = 0
        n = len(all_palindromic_subsequences)
        for i in range(n):
            for j in range(i + 1, n):
                b1, len1 = all_palindromic_subsequences[i]
                b2, len2 = all_palindromic_subsequences[j]
                if b1 & b2  == 0:  
                    cur_prod = len1 * len2
                    mx = max(mx, cur_prod)
        return mx
            
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        res = 0
        def pali(arr):
            s = "".join(arr)
            return s == s[::-1]
        
        def dfs(idx, a, b):
            nonlocal res
            if idx >= len(s):
                if pali(a) and pali(b):
                    res = max(res, len(a) * len(b))
                return
            
            a.append(s[idx])
            dfs(idx + 1, a, b)
            a.pop()

            b.append(s[idx])
            dfs(idx + 1, a, b)
            b.pop()

            dfs(idx + 1, a, b)
        dfs(0, [], [])
        return res
            
        
```

## time: o(2^n)
## space: o(2^n)
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        
        n = len(s);
        
        ##create a hashmap as follows
        
        pali = {} # bitmask of sub pailndrome : length of that palindrome
        
        for mask in range(1 , 1<<n): # 1<<n == 1<<2**n
            
            ## create an empyty string to convert back the bitmask
            subseq = ""
            for i in range(n):
                
                ## the above line inidcates that and operation gives 1 
                if(mask & (1<<i)):
                    subseq += s[i];
            ## check if the subsequnce string is palindrome        
            if subseq == subseq[::-1]:
                ##then assing the key and value in hashmap
                pali[mask] = len(subseq)
                
                
        res = 0
        
        for m1 in pali:
            for m2 in pali:
                if(m1 & m2) == 0: #disjoint
                    res = max(res , pali[m1] * pali[m2])
        return res

solutions.content:
Everyone here writes perfect and optimized code. I am here to mix things up with my pretty bad code. Here are two approaches that are both very bad.


# Approach 1
The code is pretty self explanatory but I will try to give a high level summary in the following points:
- First I have taken 4 variables `first, rev_first, second, rev_second`. I use these to store first subsequence, reverse of first subsequence, second subsequence and reverse of second subsequence.
- I am traversing through the string recursively and choosing for every index if it should go in first or it should go in second subsequence. I am also maintaining the reverse of both of these substrings by adding to the back of a deque so that in the end I could compare first with rev_first and second with rev_second and find out if both of these constructed subsequences are palindromes.
- The nature of backtracking makes sure that these subsequences are disjoint subsequences. And we check for if they are palindromes later. That completes our formation of dijoint plaindromic subsequences and we just check if what we have now is greater than our current stores answer in the line `self.ret = max(self.ret, len(first)*len(second))`


# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        N = len(s)
        self.ret = 1
        def backtrack(idx):
            if idx >= N:
                if first == rev_first and second == rev_second:
                    self.ret = max(self.ret, len(first)*len(second))
                return 
            backtrack(idx+1)
            first.append(s[idx])
            rev_first.appendleft(s[idx])
            backtrack(idx+1)
            first.pop()
            rev_first.popleft()
            second.append(s[idx])
            rev_second.appendleft(s[idx])
            backtrack(idx+1)
            second.pop()
            rev_second.popleft()
        first, second = deque([]), deque([])
        rev_first, rev_second = deque([]), deque([])
        backtrack(0)
        return self.ret
            
```

# Approach 2
We do everything same as approach 1 but instead of maintaining a rev_first and a rev_second we just call isPali function on first and second which checks if they are palindromes or not. 

```

class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        def isPali(seq):
            i, j = 0, len(seq)-1
            while i<j:
                if seq[i] != seq[j]:
                    return False
                i += 1
                j -= 1
            return True
        N = len(s)
        self.ret = 1
        def backtrack(idx):
            if idx >= N:
                if isPali(first) and isPali(second):
                    self.ret = max(self.ret, len(first)*len(second))
                return 
            backtrack(idx+1)
            # calling after adding to first subsequence
            first.append(s[idx])
            backtrack(idx+1)
            first.pop()
            #calling after adding to second subsequence
            second.append(s[idx])
            backtrack(idx+1)
            second.pop()
        first, second = [], []
        backtrack(0)
        return self.ret


```

# Time and space = ?
idk, I guess it should be (3^n) * 2n.
Because, there are a total of 3^n possibilities that we go into and in each one of them we check if first and second are palindromes which is O(n) for both.

I think, time = O(3^n * 2n)
Which truncates to O(3^n)

I am not sure though. Upvote if you also like simple solutions like me and are easily intimidated by stuff like bitmask that other people have effortlessly used in other solutions here. LOL. Happy Coding !!

maximum-product-of-palindromic-substrings
solutions.content:
# Intuition
We recursively explore all possible combinations of splitting the input string 's' into two substrings. We start with empty strings as the initial substrings and iterate through each character in 's'. At each position, we have three options: add the character to the first substring, add it to the second substring, or don't add it to either substring. We update the maximum product of lengths if both substrings formed are palindromes. We continue this exploration until we reach the end of the input string. Finally, we return the maximum product of lengths obtained.
# Approach
Step-by-step approach:

1. Start with the main function maxProduct that takes the input string s as a parameter.

2. Convert the string s into a character array using the toCharArray method.

3. Call the helper function dfs with initial values: empty strings for str1 and str2, position 0, and maximum 0.

4. In the dfs function:
    * Check if the position is at the end of the character array charArray.
    * If so, check if both str1 and str2 are valid palindromes using the isValid function.
    * If both strings are valid, update the maximum by calculating the product of their lengths and taking the maximum value.
    * Return the updated maximum.
    * If the position is not at the end, continue the exploration:
        - Call dfs recursively with str1 appended with charArray[position], keeping str2 unchanged.
        - Call dfs recursively with str2 appended with charArray[position], keeping str1 unchanged.
        - Call dfs recursively with both str1 and str2 unchanged.
        - Take the maximum value among the three recursive calls and return it.

5. Implement the isValid function:
    * Initialize i to 0 and j to the length of the string str minus 1.
    * Use a while loop to iterate while i is less than j.
    * Inside the loop, check if the characters at indices i and j are not equal. If so, return false.
    * After the loop, return true.

6. Return the final maximum value obtained from the dfs function in the maxProduct function.
# Complexity
- Time complexity: O(2^N)

- Space complexity: O(N)

# Code
```
class Solution {
  public int maxProduct(String s) {
    return dfs(s.toCharArray(), "", "", 0, 0); // call dfs with initial values
  }

  public int dfs( // dfs function
    char[] charArray,
    String str1,
    String str2,
    int position,
    int maximum
  ) {
    if (position == charArray.length) { // if position is at the end of charArray
      if (isValid(str1) && isValid(str2)) { // if both strings are valid
        maximum = Math.max(maximum, str1.length() * str2.length()); // update maximum
      }
      return maximum; // return maximum
    }
    return Math.max(
      dfs(charArray, str1 + charArray[position], str2, position + 1, maximum), // call dfs with str1 + charArray[position]
      Math.max(
        dfs(charArray, str1, str2 + charArray[position], position + 1, maximum), // call dfs with str2 + charArray[position]
        dfs(charArray, str1, str2, position + 1, maximum) // call dfs with charArray[position] not added to either string
      )
    );
  }

  public boolean isValid(String str) {
    int i = 0; // initialize i to 0
    int j = str.length() - 1; // initialize j to str.length() - 1
    while (i < j) { // loop through str
      if (str.charAt(i++) != str.charAt(j--)) { // if characters at i and j are not equal
        return false; // return false
      }
    }
    return true; // return true
  }
}
```

# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:O((2**n)*2n)
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:O(2**n)
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        # number of subsequences 2**n
        # from bitmask --> subsequence
        # logic & --> disjoint palindrome subsequnces 

        n = len(s)
        maskToLength = {} # bitmask : length
        maxProduct = 0
        
        def getSubsequence(mask):
            subseq = ""
            for i in range(n):
                if mask & (1 << i):
                    subseq += s[n-1-i]
            return subseq
        
        def isPalindrome(s):
            return s == s[::-1]

        for mask in range(1, 1 << n):
            subseq = getSubsequence(mask)
            if isPalindrome(subseq):
                maskToLength[mask] = len(subseq)
        
        for mask1, length1 in maskToLength.items():
            for mask2, length2 in maskToLength.items():
                if mask1 & mask2 == 0:
                    maxProduct = max(maxProduct, length1*length2)
        return maxProduct
        
        


        

            
                


        
        
            


        
```

solutions.content:
# Intuition
<!-- Describe your first thoughts on how to solve this problem. -->

# Approach
<!-- Describe your approach to solving the problem. -->

# Complexity
- Time complexity:
<!-- Add your time complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

- Space complexity:
<!-- Add your space complexity here, e.g. $$O(n)$$ -->

# Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s):
        n = len(s)

        @lru_cache(None)
        def backtrack(idx,path1,path2):
            if idx == n:
                if path1 == path1[::-1] and path2 == path2[::-1]:
                    res.append(len(path1)*len(path2))

            for i in range(idx,n):
                backtrack(i+1,path1+s[i],path2)
                backtrack(i+1,path1,path2+s[i])
                backtrack(i+1,path1,path2)

        res = []
        backtrack(0,"","")
        return max(res)

        
        
        
```

```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        ans = 1
        
        dp = dict()
        def check(seq):
            if seq in dp:
                return dp[seq]
            lo, hi = 0, len(seq) - 1
            while lo < hi and seq[lo] == seq[hi]:
                lo += 1
                hi -= 1
            if hi <= lo: # if current seq is polindrom, than we can include polidroms excluding cahrs from  left and right
                lo, hi = 0, len(seq)
                while lo <= hi:
                    new_seq = seq[lo:hi]
                    if new_seq in dp:
                        break
                    dp[new_seq] = True
                    lo += 1
                    hi -= 1
                return True
            dp[seq] = False
            return dp[seq]
            
        def dfs(n, s1, s2):
            nonlocal ans
            if n == len(s):
                if check(tuple(s1)) and check(tuple(s2)):
                    ans = max(ans, len(s1) * len(s2))
            else:
                dfs(n + 1, s1, s2)
                s1.append(s[n])
                dfs(n + 1, s1, s2)
                s1.pop()
                s2.append(s[n])
                dfs(n + 1, s1, s2)
                s2.pop()
            return
        dfs(0, [], [])
        return ans
            
```

solutions.content:
**RECURSION**
```
class Solution:
    def solve(self, s, i, s1, s2):
        if s1 == s1[::-1] and s2 == s2[::-1]:
            #print(s1, s2)
            self.ans = max(self.ans, len(s1)*len(s2))
        if i == len(s):
            return
        self.solve(s, i+1, s1+s[i], s2)
        self.solve(s, i+1, s1, s2+s[i])
        self.solve(s, i+1, s1, s2)
    
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        self.ans = 0
        self.solve(s, 0, '', '')
        return self.ans
```

**MEMOIZATION**
```
class Solution:
    def solve(self, s, i, s1, s2):
        if s1 == s1[::-1] and s2 == s2[::-1]:
            #print(s1, s2)
            self.ans = max(self.ans, len(s1)*len(s2))
        if i == len(s):
            return
        if (i, s1, s2) in self.d:
            return
        self.d.add((i, s1, s2))
        self.solve(s, i+1, s1+s[i], s2)
        self.solve(s, i+1, s1, s2+s[i])
        self.solve(s, i+1, s1, s2)
    
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        self.ans = 0
        self.d = set()
        self.solve(s, 0, '', '')
        return self.ans

solutions.content:
### Approach

- First thing we have to do is find if the strings are disjoint. The easiest way to do this is to use Bit Masking instead of while loops.

- We will have one spot in the the input for each character. Let input be leetcodecom. We have 11 characters and each subsequence will be represented by a bit mask. Eg **ete -> 01010001000 and cdc -> 00001010100**

- Now if we run a logical and on the above bit masks, we can see that all will be 0 -> 00000000000. So the strings are disjoint.

- We will have to go through every single subsquence in the string using backtracking.

- So now for 11 characters, we can see that each combination can be made by changing some digits to 1.

- We can run a for loop from 1 to 2^11 not including 2^11 because 2^11 is not in the range of values we can get by using 11 bits [100000000000] says that we dont include any character.

- For every single subsequence, how do we know if its a palindrome?

- If we do AND operation and get a 1 then we are basically choosing that character. So we add it to the subsequence string. Then we shift one from extreme right to extreme left 11 times.

- Then we can check if the string in the previous step is a palindrome.

- To keep a track of the length of the palindromic strings, we maintain a HashMap where the key of the hashMap will be the bit masked value and the value would be the length of the string.

- The Time Complexity is O(2^n) but we run a nested for loop to calculate the product, so the TC is aactually O(4^n).

### Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        N,pali = len(s),{}

        for mask in range(1, 2 << N):
            subseq = ""
            for i in range(N):
                if mask & (1 << i):
                    subseq += s[N - i - 1] # we are adding characters starting from right to left
            if subseq == subseq[::-1]:
                pali[mask] = len(subseq)
        res = 0
        for m1 in pali:
            for m2 in pali:
                if m1 & m2 == 0: # they are disjoint
                    res = max(res,pali[m1]*pali[m2])
        return res



```

solutions.content:
#### Intuition
Classic backtracking. First looking for one pal than for other.

#### Code
```
class Solution:
    def maxProduct(self, s: str) -> int:
        used = [False for i in range(0, 13)]
        ans = 0
        cur = ""
        previous_len = 0

        def solve(i):
            nonlocal used, ans, cur, previous_len, s
            if len(cur) > 0 and cur == cur[::-1]:
                if previous_len != 0:
                    ans = max(ans, len(cur) * previous_len)
                else:
                    previous_len, t, cur = len(cur), cur, ""
                    solve(0)
                    previous_len, cur = 0, t

            for j in range(i, len(s)):
                if used[j] == False:
                    used[j], cur = True, cur + s[j]
                    solve(j + 1)
                    used[j], cur = False, cur[:-1]
        
        solve(0)
        return ans

```

People with no idea learn from DFS. People with good idea, implement DFS. People who are very learned implement DP!
perfect medium problem

Reasonable solution hint: generate all the palindromic subsequences using recursion and backtracking. Mark the index as visited and then find the longest Palindromic subsequence in the remaining unvisited string using the concept of LCS/DP starting from the longest with break condition.

T: O((N^2)*(2^N))
passing by reference is a must in such problems
Longest Common Subsequence is a Medium\nLongest Palindromic Subsequence is a Medium, that consists of LCS\nThis problem, that consists of LPS, is also a Medium
Why O(2^24) code is getting accepted?
[@kunal98p](/kunal98p) your math isn't good my friend
because thats just 4096. Way within the bounds.
no it isn\'t
this should definitely be rated \'hard\'
